title: Are Italian wines better than other wines in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: No they are not better or worse, just different. This is due to the wine cultivation laws, the terroir, and the varietals, some of which are almost ubiquitous - the merlot grape, for example, and a myriad which are autochthonous: bianchello, biancolello, erbaluce, just to name a few whites. In the lower price points you find perfectly drinkable whites, reds that compete with any other geography. In the mid-high and high pricepoints there are outstanding wines, some of which, the Barolos from Piedmont, age better than some of the French wines. It’s really a matter of taste.

Absolutely not. Italy has extraordinary wines same as lots of other countries. I am a wine fun and had marvelous wines in many other countries. Is really impossible to find out who produces the best wine because the wine production are different from one country to other. If you drink a Rivera del Duero from Spain, has nothing to do with a Super Toscano or a wonderful Bordeaux. Just find the one you like the best

Which “Italian wines” compared to which from the rest of the world? If it's a 3 Euro Lambrusco vs a Grange or Hill of Grace from Australia, open the Australian and be careful where you throw the Lambrusco away, because it might harm the steel sink in the kitchen. Now an aged Barolo pitted against a “Montagne Supérieur” (masculine form, no ‘e’) is also a very unfair fight in favour of Italy. So… “it depends” seems a good, fair and correct answer once again. Italy is a wine country and has been for literally millenia, but so are and have been France and Spain and Portugal and Switzerland and Austria and Germany. And the New World has been pretty good at learning how to turn grape juice into wine as well in the last two centuries.

Although wine was first recorded as being made in Ancient Greece, Ancient Rome soon adopted it as their own and used the huge variety of grapes grown in their different colonies to improve the existing recipe and find new ways to make it. As a result, the reason Italy is so renowned for their fine wines is simply because they have been doing it for so long and have become experts at refining it. Because of their long history with making it, the rest of the world does tend to regard Italy as home to the best wines.

It is if you are Italian. Granted i have had some excellent Italian wines. Brunello, Barolo, etc. For my taste, I would give the best wine category to France. I put Italy second, and Spain third. Germany (and Alsace, France) for the best Rieslings in the world. Jereez, Spain for the best Sherry in the world.

We cannot speak of Italian wines but of a huge galaxy of Italian wines. The same applies to those produced in other European countries such as France, Germany, Austria and Spain. The real distinction to be made is between good/genuine wines and bad/adulterated wines. All countries have both types.
Italian wines are great, but beauty is in the eye of the beholder. I have an Californian wine palate so I prefer wines made in the US. Italian wines are the best if you like them the best.

Been lucky enough to enjoy wines from all over Europe locally. All are very good. The best ones I have found and it’s all about personal taste only, were in Sardinia, and Croatia. As I said, it’s just a matter of personal taste not a hard fact. The Germans make some really great sweet white wines and non sweet.
